comment: verb forms bears, bore, borne, bearing

senses.definition: 2' bear with' If someone asks you to bear with them, they are asking you to be patient.
example: My grandparents arrived from Europe bearing gifts for the whole family
I hope the ice can bear our weight
He bore no resemblance to his father. [j33] This bank cheque bears no signature
My grandmother bore eight children[bj4]it was quite usual in those days. [j33] This cow has borne three champion calves in the last three seasons
Young families with children are bearing the brunt of the recession. [j33] Carlos bore the main burden of his mother's death, because there was no-one else to look after the children
Jackie doesn't bear up under pressure at all, but gets more and more nervous. [j33] My old car bore up very well during our trip around Australia
Please bear with me while I try to explain how this works
note: ... NOTE The form born (as in 'I was born in 1952) comes from an older spelling of borne.   5' 'verb When a tree or plant bears fruit or leaves, it produces them as part of its growing. We extend this idea by saying that someone's efforts bear fruit when we mean that their efforts are successful. Gum trees bear leaves all year round.
... WORD FAMILY 'adjective bearable' The heat is hardly bearable. [j35] 'noun bearer' She was the bearer of good news.

example: Let's go to the pub for a few beers and a couple of games of billiards

definition: Bingo is a game where you have a card with a lot of numbers on it which you cross out as someone calls them. If you are the first person to have all your numbers called out, you are the winner. You can win money or prizes.
note: ... OTHER WORDS for this are lotto or housie.
example: Let's go to the local community hall; they've got bingo on tonight

definition: A pair of binoculars[iw0][nb is a pair of short telescopes joined together which you look through to see things in the distance more clearly.
example: Take a pair of binoculars with you to the concert because you might be sitting a long way from the stage

definition: A biodegradable chemical or substance is one that can be broken down into environmentally harmless products. This is done by the sun or bacteria.
example: ...biodegradable soap powder

definition: In formal or technical language, if you bisect something, you divide it into two equal parts.

senses.definition: 0' to bits' If you take, smash or blow something to bits, it comes apart or is broken into many small pieces.
example: I need a bit of paper to write on. [j33] Watch out, there are bits of glass all over the floor! 2' '[cf2]noun A bit is also a short period of time. [cf2]Do you mind waiting for a bit? [j33] I'm just going out for a bit
' A bit is also a metal bar attached to a pair of reins which you put in a horse's mouth. You use it to help steer and control the horse
This drill bit is blunt; we'll have to sharpen it
You say something is a bit much if it's unfair or more than you can accept. [cf2]I think it's a bit much that we're expected to put up with all this noise
It's about time you did your bit. [j33] I try to do my bit around the house
'Do you mind waiting?' 'No, not a bit!' [j33] Janine, you haven't changed a bit. [j33] Mark was not a bit like his father
He'd had quite a bit to drink. [j33] Pedro earns quite a bit of money
He took the motor to bits, then tried to fix it. [j33] He threw the glass onto the floor and it smashed to bits

senses.definition: ' the bitter end' If you do something to the bitter end, you keep on doing it until it's finished, even though it's very unplea~ [chsant. In informal language, you can use the bitter end to emphasise that you mean the very end of something.
example: Strong black coffee without sugar tastes quite bitter. 2' '[cf2]adjective When the weather is bitter, it is very cold. [cf2]Put on a warm coat[bj4]there's a bitter wind blowing outside. [j33] Penguins don't seem to feel the bitter cold
It took me a long time to get over the bitter blow of her death. [j33] He's still very bitter about his dismissal
The war has been very bitter. [j33] They've been bitter enemies for years. [j33] It was a bitter divorce
The rebels swore they'd fight till the bitter end. [j33] I stayed at the party to the bitter end
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun bitterness' I like a beer with a touch of bitterness.[j35]bitterly ' It's bitterly cold today.  ' Navaz wept bitterly.

example: The soldiers bivouacked in the bush for ten days as part of their training

example: I'll have a black coffee with two sugars, please

definition: A blacksmith is someone who makes things out of iron, such as horseshoes

senses.definition: ' A blank is an empty space on a form which you have to fill in.
example: I tried to remember his name, but my mind went completely blank

Please complete all the blanks or write 'not applicable'.  5 ' blank cheque' '[cf2] A blank cheque is a cheque on which the amount that has to be paid has not been filled in. We also use it to mean an unlimited promise of support, especially financial support. [cf2]They were so impressed with our research they basically wrote us a blank cheque to pursue it. 6 ' draw a blank' '[cf2] In informal language, if you say you draw a blank when you are trying to do something, it means that you are unsuccessful. [cf2]The police realised that they'd drawn a blank in following up what they thought was a major clue to the murder
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'adverb blankly' She stared at me blankly[bj4]she'd obviously forgotten who I was.

senses.definition: ' wet blanket' You call someone a wet blanket if they never join in fun that everyone else is having, or if they try to stop other people from having fun.
example: We woke in the morning to find the whole valley covered in a blanket of snow
We think there should be a blanket ban on smoking in restaurants. [j33] 'Equipment' is a blanket term for various machines and tools
Don't be such a wet blanket[bj4]it won't do any harm. [j33] As usual Joan was a wet blanket and wanted to leave early
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'verb blanket' Fog blanketed the town.

senses.definition: ' full blast' If music is being played full blast, it's very loud.
example: There was a blast of icy wind when he opened the door

a' A blast is also an explosion
' blast off' When a rocket or spacecraft blasts off, it takes off from the ground to begin its journey into space

senses.definition: '(b) If one thing blots out another, it is in the way so that the other thing cannot be seen or heard.
example: His conviction for drink-driving will be a major blot on his reputation
Blot the surface dry without rubbing

The dark clouds blotted out the warm sun

example: The accident was caused by a blowout at high speed

definition: A blowtorch is a tool that produces an extremely hot flame

senses.definition: ' When someone blubbers, they cry noisily. If you use this word you mean that you are not sorry for them.

senses.definition: ' When someone bludges on you, they take unfair advan~ tage of you by taking or using things that you own, without any intention of repaying you.
example: It makes me mad the way some of us do all the work and others just bludge
Can I bludge a cigarette from you? [j33] The girls regularly bludge $10 from me at the weekend
It's time you got a job and stopped bludging on your parents at your age
note: [j34] ... WORD FAMILY 'noun bludge' Working in this place is a good bludge.[j35]'noun bludger' The politician claimed that many pensioners were bludgers.

senses.definition: ' out of the blue' You say something happens out of the blue if it happens suddenly and unexpectedly.

She showed enormous breadth of vision. [j33] I was impressed by the breadth of talent on display. [j33] His articles show breadth rather than depth of learning

definition: A breadwinner is someone who earns money to support other members of their family.
example: The children had to leave school to become breadwinners. [j33] In the family of ten, there are only two breadwinners. [j33] We took it in turns to be the breadwinner while the other studied

John broke his leg in the motorbike accident. [j33] He was killed, but she got away with a few broken bones
Peter borrowed my electric drill and broke it[bj4]now I'll have to get it repaired
If your employer pays you less than award rates, they are breaking the law

Can you break me off another piece of chocolate, please? [j33] The handle broke off when I picked the jug up. '  (b) '[cf2] If you break off a relationship with someone else, you end it. '  (c) '[cf2] If you break off what you are doing, you suddenly stop doing it. [cf2]They broke off their conversation when I entered the room. If something such as war, fire or disease breaks out, it suddenly begins. [cf2]A fire broke out in the plastics factory. '  (b) '[cf2] If something breaks up, it is destroyed because its components come apart. [cf2]The satellite broke up on entering the earth's atmosphere. senses.definition: ' If something has a breakdown, it stops because of a mechanical failure or a problem.
example: Our car had three breakdowns between Sydney and Darwin. [j33] There was a break~ down in talks between the unions and the employers.  2 ' '[cf2]noun A breakdown of something is a description of its separate parts. [cf2]The accountant gave me a breakdown of the figures
' If someone has a breakdown, they suffer a physical or mental collapse so that they cannot cope with their usual daily activities

' A brief is a summary prepared for a barrister by a solicitor, giving all the information about a case
The new manager's brief was to reduce costs
I'd better brief Sigrid before she goes to the meeting tomorrow
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun See brevity'. [j35]'adverb briefly' I saw her briefly the other day.  I briefly summarised my concerns.[j35]'noun briefing' We all attended a briefing before the conference.

senses.definition: 1' bring up'  (a) If you bring up children, you look after them until they have grown up.
example: The ambulance officers brought Damien round after he'd been unconscious for nearly twenty minutes

Val helped to bring up Steve's three sons. [j33] I was brought up to believe in the importance of politeness. '  (b) '[cf2] If you bring up a particular topic in a conversation or discussion, you begin to talk about it. [cf2]I wish you wouldn't keep bringing up the incident in public. [j33] There's one other point I'd like to bring up. '  (c) '[cf2] If you bring up your food, you vomit. [cf2]He got very drunk and brought up his dinner in the street

senses.definition: ' If some~ thing is brisk, it is refreshing and invigorating because it involves rapid motion.
example: He can be so brisk that he frightens people. [j33] She reorganised our files with brisk efficiency
Every evening we go for a brisk walk round the park. [j33] The brisk breeze made me feel less sleepy
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'adverb briskly' She briskly set about tidying up.  He marched briskly out of the room.

senses.definition: ' bristle with' In informal language, if you say that a place bristles with people or things, you mean that it is full of them. There are a lot of them there.
example: This brush is made from pigs' bristles. [j33] After two days without shaving, his chin was covered with bristles
The hair on the dog's back bristled and it began to growl
Pat bristled at the mention of Martin's name
The streets were bristling with police after the bank robbery
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'adjective bristly ' After a week he'd grown a bristly beard.

definition: If you browbeat someone, you make them do something that they don't really want to do. You do this by nagging them or making them feel uncomfortable so that they agree to what you want.
example: The kids always browbeat me into buying them toys. [j33] I felt browbeaten by the high-pressure sales technique

definition: A brunette is a girl or woman with brown hair
If you bear the brunt of something, you suffer the most damaging effects of it.
example: The centre of the city bore the brunt of the earthquake. [j33] Poor Ed bore the brunt of the boss's anger. [j33] Small businesses have borne the brunt of the recession

senses.definition: ' brush up' If you brush up a skill, you practise it again. If you brush up on a subject, you renew your knowledge of it.
example: Where's the scrubbing brush? [j33] ...a nail brush. [j33] ...a hair brush. [j33] ...a clothes brush
Don't forget to brush your teeth before you go to bed. [j33] You look a mess
My suit needs a good brush to get all those cat hairs off
Anjali's had a brush with his parents again. [j33] I remembered our earlier brush over the seating arrangements. [j33] Many of these teenagers have already had a brush with the law
He brushed me on the elbow and whispered in my ear. [j33] The tall grasses brushed against her legs as she ran. [j33] The cats love to brush up against us. [j33] Her lips brushed his
The ball landed in the brush, and we never found it again
Ping brushed aside all criticism. [j33] Brushing aside the crowd of reporters, he left the room. [j33] Workers' welfare has been brushed aside in the rush for profit
Since our argument, every time I try to talk to her she just brushes me off
I'd better brush up my French if we're going to Noumea for a holiday
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun brush-off' She gives me the brush-off whenever I try to talk to her.

example: I refused to go to the cemetery for my father's burial

senses.definition: 1' burn up' If you say an engine burns up fuel, you mean that it uses too much fuel.
example: I'd just got the wood in the barbecue burning nicely. [j33] The old warehouse burnt throughout the night. [j33] If the paper's damp, it won't burn properly.  2' '[cf2]verb If you burn something, you set it on fire and allow it to be consumed. [cf2]It's illegal to burn your garbage in the backyard. [j33] He burnt all his papers the night before he died
The toast's been burnt black. [j33] Vera burnt the roast again. [j33] It's a real pain scraping the burnt bits out of the saucepan
I burnt my fingers on the stove. [j33] Don't lie in the sun too long[bj4]you'll burn your back. [j33] The acid burnt his skin
The sand on the beach burnt beneath their feet. [j33] I came home to find all the lights still burning. [j33] The fabric was patterned with burning yellows and oranges
Her remark made him burn with anger. [j33] I still burnt with love for him
That's a nasty burn! [j33] 30% of his body was covered with burns. [j33] ...a chemical burn
Their house burned down in a bushfire. [j33] He tried to burn down his own factory for the insurance.  9' burn off' '[cf2] If you burn off land, you clear it of trees and bushes by fire

We sat by our fire until it burnt itself out. [j33] Some bushfires in remote areas have been left to burn themselves out. '  (b) '[cf2] If you burn yourself out, you get into a state where you can't work or be creative any more, because you've worked too hard in the past. [cf2]Many of these young entrepreneurs burn themselves out by the time they're forty. '  (c) '[cf2] When a building is burned out, the inside is destroyed by fire, leaving only its outside walls. [cf2]The school was burned out in the big fire. [j33] The barn was reduced to a burned-out shell. '  (d) '[cf2] If an engine or machine burns out, it stops working because it is damaged by the heat that the moving parts create. [cf2]My electric drill needs to be fixed because it's burned out
A four-wheel drive is fun, but it really burns up fuel

The toast's been burnt black. [j33] Vera burnt the roast again. [j33] It's a real pain scraping the burnt bits out of the saucepan
I burnt my fingers on the stove. [j33] Don't lie in the sun too long[bj4]you'll burn your back. [j33] The acid burnt his skin
The sand on the beach burnt beneath their feet. [j33] I came home to find all the lights still burning. [j33] The fabric was patterned with burning yellows and oranges
Her remark made him burn with anger. [j33] I still burnt with love for him
That's a nasty burn! [j33] 30% of his body was covered with burns. [j33] ...a chemical burn
Their house burned down in a bushfire. [j33] He tried to burn down his own factory for the insurance.  9' burn off' '[cf2] If you burn off land, you clear it of trees and bushes by fire

We sat by our fire until it burnt itself out. [j33] Some bushfires in remote areas have been left to burn themselves out. '  (b) '[cf2] If you burn yourself out, you get into a state where you can't work or be creative any more, because you've worked too hard in the past. [cf2]Many of these young entrepreneurs burn themselves out by the time they're forty. '  (c) '[cf2] When a building is burned out, the inside is destroyed by fire, leaving only its outside walls. [cf2]The school was burned out in the big fire. [j33] The barn was reduced to a burned-out shell. '  (d) '[cf2] If an engine or machine burns out, it stops working because it is damaged by the heat that the moving parts create. [cf2]My electric drill needs to be fixed because it's burned out
A four-wheel drive is fun, but it really burns up fuel

senses.definition: ' buy up' If you buy up something, you buy all that is available or as much of it as you can.
example: I need to buy some new shoes. [j33] Money can't buy happiness
The police won't buy that story
Carlos bought his partner out of their business
The property developer bought up all the best blocks in the district
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun buy' These new shoes were a good buy[bj4]they only cost $50.[j35]'noun buyer' John is a buyer for a large store in town.

senses.definition: ' give a buzz'  (a) In informal language, if you say that you give someone a buzz, you mean that you telephone them.
example: We could hear the buzz of conversation in the next room. [j33] The buzz from the chainsaw was driving me mad
Our trip to Europe was a real buzz. [j33] John gets a buzz out of listening to music
Buzz off, mate, I'm busy

Trish gave me a buzz on Friday to tell me the good news. '  (b) '[cf2] In informal language, if you say that something gives you a buzz, you mean that it makes you more alert. It stimulates you. [cf2]Coffee always gives me a buzz
note: [j34] ... WORD FAMILY 'verb buzz' The fly buzzed around my head.  The room was buzzing with conversation. [j35]'noun buzzer' If you need the nurse, just press the buzzer.

senses.definition: ' If you have a bye in a round of a competition, you have no opponent for that round and so you miss a turn. This often happens if there is an uneven number of teams or competitors[bj4]so each one has to have a bye.
example: We've got a bye this weekend in hockey[bj4]at least we get ours over with early in the season

senses.definition: b' A bypass is also a surgical operation on your heart. In the operation artificial tubes are inserted to make the flow of blood go around a blocked or diseased part of your heart.
example: He bypassed the sensitive issue in his speech. [j33] She complained that she'd been bypassed in the decision-making process. [j33] The new expressway bypasses the town
Business in this town will be ruined when the bypass is built
He had a double bypass last year
